t: What Is the Measure of My Days?
To the choirmaster: to Jeduthun. A Psalm of David.
I*pn said, “I will guard my ways, that*ld I may not sin with my tongue; I*ln will guard my mouth with a muzzle, so*ld long as the wicked are in my presence.”
I*ln was mute and silent; I*ld held my peace to no avail, and*ln my distress grew worse.
My*ld heart became hot within me. As*ln I mused, the fire burned; then*ld I spoke with my tongue:
“O*pn Lord,*s make me know my end and*ld what is the measure of my days; let*ld me know how fleeting I am!
Behold,*ln you have made my days a few handbreadths, and*ld my lifetime is as nothing before you. Surely*ln all mankind stands as a mere breath! Selah*ig
Surely*ld a man goes about as a shadow! Surely*ln for nothing they are in turmoil; man*ld heaps up wealth and does not know who will gather!
“And*pn now, O Lord, for what do I wait? My*ld hope is in you.
Deliver*ln me from all my transgressions. Do*ld not make me the scorn of the fool!
I*ln am mute; I do not open my mouth, for*ld it is you who have done it.
Remove*ln your stroke from me; I*ld am spent by the hostility of your hand.
When*ln you discipline a man with*ld rebukes for sin, you*ln consume like a moth what is dear to him; surely*ld all mankind is a mere breath! Selah*ig
“Hear*pn my prayer, O Lord,*s and*ld give ear to my cry; hold*ld not your peace at my tears! For*ln I am a sojourner with you, a*ld guest, like all my fathers.
Look*ln away from me, that I may smile again, before*ld I depart and am no more!”
